case_name: Civil Appeal No. 88 of 1956, Civil Appeal Nos. 91 and 92 of 1958

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 88 of 1956 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated February 11, 1954, of the Madras High Court in Civil Revision Petition No. 921 of 1952.

T. A. No. 113 of 1951 .

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and decree dated March 10, 1955, of the Bombay High Court in Appeals Nos. 66/X and 67/X of 1954, arising out of the judgment and decree dated February 15, 1954, of the said High Court in Suits Nos. 1693 of 1949 and 105 of 1950, respectively.

facts.text: 90 bundles of brass circles were consigned to the respondent at Madras from Bombay per S. S. Fakira.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal from the Madras High Court was in respect of a companysignment of 90 bundles of brass circles which were companysigned to the respondent at Madras from Bombay to Madras per S. S. Fakira, a Steamer belonging to the East and West Steamship Co.

facts.text: S. S. Fakira arrived in Madras on August 1, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The Ship arrived in Madras on August 1, 1948, and 78 out of the 90 bundles were delivered on August 25, 1948, to the appellant through his clearing agent, the second respondent.

facts.text: 78 out of 90 bundles were delivered on August 25, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: and 78 out of the 90 bundles were delivered on August 25, 1948, to the appellant through his clearing agent, the second respondent. Five more bundles were delivered on September 25, 1948.

facts.text: Five more bundles were delivered on September 25, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Five more bundles were delivered on September 25, 1948. After some companyrespondence between the Shipping Company and the first respondent regarding the seven bundles number, delivered the appellant companypany repudiated finally the respondents claim on March 24, 1950.

facts.text: Shipping company repudiated the claim on March 24, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: delivered the appellant companypany repudiated finally the respondents claim on March 24, 1950. The first respondent brought the present suit on June 27, 1950, claiming Rs. 1,023-5-0 as companypensation-Rs. 974-13-0 for the value of the undelivered goods

facts.text: Suit brought on June 27, 1950, claiming Rs. 1,023-5-0.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent brought the present suit on June 27, 1950, claiming Rs. 1,023-5-0 as companypensation-Rs. 974-13-0 for the value of the undelivered goods and Rs. 48-8-0 as the profit of which he had been deprived.

facts.text: S. S. Tweedsmuir Park, S. S. Finnamore Hill arrived in Bombay on or about September 10, 1948; S. S. Ismalia on September 6, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: S. S. Tweedsmuir and S. Finnamore Hill arrived in the port of Bombay on or about September 10, 1948, and steamer Ismalia arrived in Bombay on September 6,1948.

facts.text: Vessels discharged cargoes to docks of Trustees of Port of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The vessels discharged their cargoes alongside on to the docks belonging to the Trustees of the Port of Bombay.

facts.text: Unable to obtain 164 bags from Ismalia, 869 from Finnamore, 1,657 from Tweedsmuir Park.

anchor.surface_text: but were unable to obtain delivery of 164 bags out of the companysignment sent by Ismalia, 869 bags out of the companysignment sent by Finnamore and 1,657 bags out of the companysignment sent by Tweedsmuir Park.

facts.text: Suit claim Rs. 1,10,323-8-0 for non-delivered bags.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was brought on a claim of Rs. 1,10,323-8-0 as companypensation for the bags number delivered.

facts.text: S.S. Finnamore Hill completed discharging on 19th September 1948, Ismalia on 25th September 1948, Tweedsmuir Park on 27th September 1948.

facts.text: 6,000 bags of coconut from Cochin and 4,733 bags of copra and coconuts from Badagara consigned to Bombay by steamer Bharatjal.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 91 of 1958 is in respect of a companysignment of 6,000 bags of companyonut from Cochin and 4,733 bags of companyra and companyonuts from Badagara companysigned to the plaintiffs for carriage to Bombay by the steamer Bharatjal belonging to the appellant, the Bharat Lines Ltd.

facts.text: Steamer Bharatjal arrived in Bombay Port in the middle of September 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The steamer arrived in Bombay Port some time in the middle of September, 1948.

facts.text: Failed to obtain 596 bags from Badagara and 470 from Cochin consignments.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs however failed to obtain delivery of 596 bags from the Badagara companysignment and 470 bags from the Cochin companysignment.

facts.text: Suit brought on December 5, 1949, claim Rs. 1,05,726-1-6.

anchor.surface_text: They brought the suit on December 5, 1949, against the shipping companypany, the Bharat Lines Ltd., and also against the Trustees of the Port of Bombay on a claim of Rs. 1,05,726-1- 6

facts.text: Trial court decreed suit for Rs. 974-13-0 on May 4, 1954 after remand.

anchor.surface_text: After remand the trial companyrt on May 4, 1954, decreed the suit for a sum of Rs. 974-13-0.

facts.text: Special leave to appeal obtained on October 11, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: It was after that date that the Shipping Company applied for and obtained from this Court special leave to appeal on October 11, 1954.

issues.text: Does the word 'loss' as used in the 3rd clause of paragraph 6 of Art. III include loss sustained by the owners of the goods when the carrier fails to deliver the whole or part of the cargo shipped?

anchor.surface_text: The first and the most important of these questions is as regards the meaning of the word loss as used in the said clause. Does it mean only such loss as occurs when one says the goods have been lost or does it include also such loss as is sustained by the owners of the goods-whether the shipper or the consignee-when the carrier fails to deliver the whole or part of the cargo shipped ?

issues.text: Does the 3rd clause of paragraph 6 of Art. III only prescribe a rule of limitation or does it provide for the extinction of the right to compensation?

anchor.surface_text: The second question that arises for consideration is whether this clause only prescribes a rule of limitation or also provides for the extinction of the right to compensation after a certain period of time.

issues.text: What is the date on which the goods not delivered should have been delivered for the purposes of the 3rd clause of paragraph 6 of Art. III?

anchor.surface_text: The next question is as regards the ascertainment of the date on which the goods not delivered should have been delivered for the purposes of this clause.

issues.answer: when the ship leaves the port of discharge

issues.text: Is the requirement in the bill of lading as regards the time within which notice of claim must be made void as being against the 8th paragraph of Art. III?

anchor.surface_text: Apart from these questions as regards the interpretation of the 3rd clause of paragraph 6 of Art. III, it will be necessary to consider also whether the requirement in the bill of lading as regards the time within which the notice of claim must be made in order that the carrier may be responsible is void as being against the 8th paragraph of Art. III.

holdings.text: The word 'loss' in the third clause of the 6th paragraph of Art. III of the Schedule to the Carriage of Goods by Sea Act means and includes any loss caused to a shipper or a consignee by reason of the inability of the ship or the carrier to deliver part or whole of the goods, to whatever reason such failure may be due.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual and contextual interpretation within Art. III; unqualified 'loss' includes loss to owner from non-delivery; distinguishes insurance cases; ensures uniformity with Hague Rules.

holdings.text: The third clause of paragraph 6 of Art. III discharges the carrier and ship from all liability, effecting total extinction of the right to compensation, not merely a rule of limitation.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Ordinary grammatical sense and international uniformity; distinguishes extinction of right from remedy; Limitation Act acknowledgments inapplicable post-extinction.

holdings.text: For the purposes of the third clause of paragraph 6 of Art. III, the date when the goods should have been delivered is the date when the ship by which the goods were contracted to be carried has left the port at which delivery was to be made.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Nature of sea carriage fixes delivery between arrival and departure; bill of lading terms and port custom confirm; distinguishes rail carriage cases under Limitation Act.

holdings.text: The stipulation in the bill of lading requiring notice of claim within one month from the date of arrival of the ship is null and void as it offends against paragraph 8 of Art. III.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Directly lessens liability otherwise than provided in Rules; repugnant to Art. III para 8 nullity clause.

holdings.text: The suits in Civil Appeals Nos. 91 and 92 of 1958 are not maintainable as they were not brought within one year from the date when the ships left the port of discharge.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of interpreted clause to undisputed facts of non-delivery and suit filing dates.

holdings.text: Civil Appeal No. 88 of 1956 is infructuous as the decree in the suit has become final.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural finality of underlying decree renders appeal academic.

precedents.citation: State Line Ltd. v. Foscold 1 [...] 1 1932 A.C. 328

anchor.surface_text: it is helpful to remember in this connection the caution uttered by Lord Atkin in State Line Ltd. v. Foscold 1 about the importance of giving words in these rules their plain meaning, and number to companyour ones interpretation by companysidering whether a meaning otherwise plain should be avoided if it alters the previous law. After stating that this caution would be well founded if the Act merely purported to companyify the law, he went on to observe- But if this is the canon of companystruction in regard to a companyifying Act, still more does it apply to an Act like the present which is number intended 1 1932 A.C. 328.

precedents.cited_proposition: Importance of giving words in the rules their plain meaning without predilection for former law, as the Act results from international conference for uniformity
precedents.cited_holding: still more does it apply to an Act like the present which is not intended to codify the English law, but is the result of an international conference intended to unify certain rules relating to bills of lading

precedents.citation: Spens v. The Union Marine Insurance Co. Ltd. 1 [...] 1 1868 L.R. 3 C.P. 427

anchor.surface_text: Reliance was sought to be placed on behalf of the appellants in the two Bombay appeals on Spens v. The Union Marine Insurance Co. Ltd. 1 . What had happened in that case was that cotton belonging to different owners was shipped in bales specifically marked, including 43 bales belonging to the plaintiffs. In the course of the voyage the ship was wrecked all the cotton was more or less damaged, some of it was lost, some was so damaged that it had to be sold before reaching the port and marks on a very large number of the bales were so obliterated by sea water that numbere of the cotton that was lost or sold and only a portion of what was carried to the port companyld be identified as belonging to any particular companysignment. The plaintiffs had insured the goods with the defendant companypany against the usual risks. The question 1 1868 L.R. 3 C.P. 427.

precedents.case_name: Spens v The Union Marine Insurance Co Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: No total loss of consignment where goods mixed and unidentifiable due to shipwreck and sea damage under insurance policy

precedents.citation: Sandeman Sons v. Tyzack and Branfoot Steamship Co. Ltd. 1 [...] 1 1913 A.C. 680, 697

anchor.surface_text: In cases of such mixture of cargo of different owners it was pointed out by Lord Moulton in Sandeman Sons v. Tyzack and Branfoot Steamship Co. Ltd. 1  which was cited by the learned Solicitor-General himself It may well be that they companyld assert the position of joint owners in the mixed cargo, and as such take action against any person who sought to get possession of it or companyvert it to his own use. But it does number follow that the ship-owners would have performed their companytract of carriage. Their duty is to deliver the goods entrusted to them for carriage, and they do number perform that duty if all that the companysignee obtains is a right to claim as tenant in companymon a mixture of those goods with the goods of other people. No doubt, if such a right is of some value, and the companysignee avails himself of it, the shipowners are entitled to credit for whatever value the goods possessed if they were delivered 1 1913 A.C. 680, 697. mixed up with some extraneous substance which lessened their value or companypelled the companysignee to go to expense in separating it out.

precedents.case_name: Sandeman Sons v Tyzack and Branfoot Steamship Co Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: Shipowners fail to perform contract if consignee receives only tenant-in-common share of mixed cargo; non-delivery constitutes breach
precedents.cited_holding: Their duty is to deliver the goods entrusted to them for carriage, and they do not perform that duty if all that the consignee obtains is a right to claim as tenant in common a mixture of those goods with the goods of other people.
